awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Transforming Teaching of Structural Analysis through Mobile Augmented Reality
awd_abstract_narration:
Structural Analysis is an introductory core course that is taught in almost all civil engineering, architectural engineering, and construction undergraduate programs across the U.S. Previous research unveils students' deficits in understanding the behavior of structural elements in a three-dimensional (3D) context due to the shortcomings of traditional lecturing approaches. In particular, such approaches often put too much emphasis on the analysis of individual structural members, thereby falling short in providing a solid, easy-to-follow, and holistic approach to comprehending and analyzing complex structures with a large number of interconnected elements.  This research is transforming existing teaching pedagogy in structural analysis and filling a major gap in how structural engineering is currently taught to the nation's future workforce in U.S. institutions. 

In this project, mobile augmented reality (AR) is used to superimpose views of the real world with computer generated 3D models of structures under load. In doing so, the potential of AR for improving learning and increasing student engagement in the learning process is being systematically assessed.  Building upon theoretical perspectives on how people learn, this project is also examining if pedagogy involving AR creates an effective learning environment for students, as well as if it enhances adaptive flexibility, which is deemed to be essential to be a successful engineer in the 21st Century. The broader impacts of this project extend beyond its confines through outreach activities such as integrating AR technology into lower-level engineering courses that aim to increase the number of ethnically-diverse students pursuing STEM degrees.  The learning modules integrating AR into teaching of structural analysis will be made available online.  A website and online repository are to include specific details about the learning objectives, implementation procedures, and instructor reflections on things to consider while implementing the teaching techniques.  The developed software components and 3D models will be open source.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

por.por_cntn:
This study investigated the use of augmented reality (AR) to help students transfer abstract knowledge about structural analysis concepts into real world situations; it was a collaborative effort between Iowa State University, Texas A&M University, and Oregon State University. Specific objectives included:

(1)   developing effective ways of teaching structural analysis though the use of AR including the creation of a tablet computer-based software application.

(2)   investigating how the software application impacted students’ learning of structural analysis by comparing student groups who learned using the software application with those who learned using traditional methods.

(3)   investigating how the software application impacted student engagement.

Experienced structural analysts enhance their understanding of structural systems by visualizing how they will deflect and deform under various loads such as wind, snow, moving vehicles, occupants, furniture, and/or the self-weight of the structure. The location and shape of those movements give hints about what parts of the structure in in tension, compression or under the influence of other types of structural stress, allowing the analyst to double check detailed calculations and gain a contextual understanding of structural behavior that will influence design decisions. Such visualization is challenging for novice analysts (including almost all students) because the actual movements are so small that they are imperceptible and because structural elements in many buildings that would be handy examples at an institution of higher learning are embedded behind architectural elements and out of sight.

Students are often finding motivation for learning when the learning task is relevant to their environment. In the case of students learning structural analysis, structures on their own campus are a resource. The research team developed the AR application so that students could point a tablet computer camera on local structure, or a picture of that structure and the application would recognize the structure and overlay a schematic representation of the hidden structural elements in front of the acquired image. Then the students could add virtual loads such as wind, snow, and crowds of occupants and visualize exaggerated deflections and deformation of the structural elements. This demonstrated to the students how their effort to learn structural analysis was necessary to provide safety and comfort for occupants of a variety of typical on campus structure such as an enclosed skywalk, a landmark clocktower that contained a carillon, a prominent historic building with a gabled roof, and the structural frame of the building in which most structural analysis classes were taught. Figure 1 shows the user interface of the AR app for each of the four structures.

Five modules were developed to match the five virtual structural schematics were created to overlay on images of the actual on campus structures. To compare the performance of the AR application with traditional teaching methods, two sections of the same structural analysis class was taught by the same instructor, one using the AR application and associated newly developed lessons and one using traditional teaching methods. For all students, a pretest was given before the lessons were taught and a post-test was given after the lessons were taught. Students also responded to a questionnaire asking for their perception regarding engagement in the lessons and their confidence in what they learned. Professional instructional experts observed, and recorded indications of student collaboration, engagement and enthusiasm and faculty members were interviewed to ascertain their perception of benefits and concerns for incorporating the AR application into structural analysis instruction.

Comparison of the pre and post tests indicated a weak trend (not statistically significant) toward better performance for students who were taught with AR application. Indications of student engagement and enthusiasm were favorable. Faculty member interviews indicated interest in adoption of the AR application as a teaching method if there is proper support with robust lesson plans and that technological aspects of the application were reliable.

The outcome of this investigation serves as proof of concept for teaching structural analysis using an augmented reality application on a tablet computer. Currently the application is customized with images and schematic structural overlays for the Iowa State University Campus. Next steps to encourage wider adoption would be to recode the application with modular architecture so that instructional and information technology experts could swap images, schematics, and structural analysis model to customize the application for their local campus. Industry wide advances which would result in faster image recognition and registration for tablet computers would greatly enhance the performance of the application when students use it outdoors capturing the target model of the actual building instead of targeting pictures of the building in a classroom or lab.
